Play continues until all cards are matched. The player left with the Joker/Gorilla Card is the Monkeys Uncle. Now its time for Go-Go Gorilla! Separate the card deck by color giving one color to each team/player. At the word Go! each team/player races to put their cards in alphabetical order from A to Z. The first player to finish takes the Joker/Gorilla Card and yells Go-Go Gorilla! Two other game versions promise loads of fun.

Ages 3 and up

title: Number Race
types: Card Game Children's Game Educational Math Number
description:
Learn to add  subtract as you play! Roll the die  move your piece to that card where a calculation waits to be solved. The first level covers numbers 1-20  the second covers 1-100. Self-correcting: answers on the backs of cards. Be the first to reach the goal  win.

For ages 6 and up.

Apparently a different game from the same-German-titled Erstes Rechnen.

title: Sketch & Guess
description:
How are your drawing skills ? Place the 42 wooden picture squares face down on the table where everyone can reach them, and have each player pick a square and place it face down in front of them. The first player takes the chalkboard and looks at the object that is shown on this wooden picture square, without showing any of the other players. Then he does his best to draw the picture on the wooden square and shows his drawing to the other players. The first player to correctly guess the object marks an x in one of his four squares. When one player has an x in all four of his squares, the game is over and he wins.

Ages 3 and up

title: Tell-A-Story
description:
Lets Play! There are many stories waiting to be discovered and told! Each player uses their memory skills to try to be the first player to collect all five story cards about a single character. Once all of the players have collected all of their story cards, they arrange their cards to tell a story of their choice. Maybe the kitten unraveled the sweater and rolled the yarn into a tidy ball. Or maybe the clever kitten started with the ball of yarn and knit his very own sweater! Encourages children to develop their imagination and creativity as well as logical thinking and language skills.

Ages 4 and up

Awards

1990 Årets Børnespil, Childrens Game of the Year Denmark

title: The Rainbow Fish Game
description:
Lets Play! Just like in the book, the Rainbow Fish shares hi glimmering scales with the other fish in the ocean. Divide the playing cards by color and give each player the pile of cards of the color they chose. Then each player turns two of their cards face up in front of them. On your turn, roll the die and move the playing piece that number of spaces in either direction. Your goal is to reach the picture of the fish that matches one of the cards you have turned up in front of you. When you do this, put the card youve matched in the middle of the game board and then turn up another card from you pile. If you roll the rainbow fish on your turn, you get to move to one of the pictures on the game board that matches one of your cards, and you get to choose another player to do the same. Look out for the shark, because if he turns up on the die, you lose your turn. The first player to get rid of all of their cards wins!

Ages 5 and up

title: Treasure Hunt
description:
Be the fastest captain and be the first to visit all of the islands. Roll the die to see if you can get the biggest waves to help you move across the water to all of the different islands. At each island, you collect a different kind of treasure. If you roll a storm, the waves have tossed you around and you can switch places with any of the other boats. But watch out for the pirates flag, because hes going to take away someones treasure - and it could be yours! The first player to collect a treasure from each island wins the game.

Ages 4 and up

title: Rainbow Fish and Friends
description:
Get ready for fun with Rainbow Fish and his friends! Shuffle all of the cards and put them in a pile where everyone can reach them. On your turn, turn over the top card and show it to everyone. If it shows either Rainbow Fish or one of his friends, you put this card face up in front of you and keep drawing from the pile. Continue adding cards to the one already in front of you as long as this is new friend. But dont get too greedy - if you turn over a Wanda (stop) card, you lose all of the friends youve collected on this turn! The first player to collect Rainbow Fish and one of each of his five friends wins the game.

Ages 4 and up

title: Snap, Clap & Slap
description:
Lets Play! Are you fast enough to keep up with the crazy pace? Each player gets the same number of cards that will be played on the two receiver piles set up at the beginning of the game. Take your cards and make four piles and place them face up in front of you. Now its going to get fun! Everyone races to play their cards on the receiver piles at the same time. But its not just speed you need - you have to match colors and perform actions before you can play your cards. So, snap, clap,  slap your way to being the first one to get rid of all of your cards and you win the game. But dont get caught making a goof, or youll have to add to your cards, which will put you behind. Wild cards and stop cards add to the excitement.

Ages 7 and up.

title: Fantasyland
description:
A children's game about Rudi the giant trying to catch goblins.

Ages 6 and up.

title: Frog Rally
description:
Will you be the first frog to make it to the pond ? Roll the die to determine which frog leg you have to hold onto - and then pull the frog as far forward (for green or blue) or backward (for red or yellow) until the string is pulled tight. After each pull you will be in a new position in the race and must fix the frogs legs so that both front and back legs are the same length. Roll the frog symbol and you get a free move forward. But if you roll the car symbol, this means danger so you have to take a move back. The winner is the first player to reach the pond. 
In the original Perlhuhn version, you didn't have to fix the legs to the same length after your move, but could decide freely, therefore putting an element of risk in it at your own choice.

title: Planetaire
description:
From the rules:

Planetaire is a game of planetary war.  From the surface, through the atmosphere, and into outer space, two players battle using fighters, mother ships, killer satellites and beam tanks.

Description:

Planetaire is an abstract strategy game played on a board of four concentric circular tracks (orbits). A player takes one action on a turn; an action can be moving a piece, attacking with a piece, or loading or unloading fighters (which can be carried by motherships).

The different pieces move and attack differently. Fighters move two spaces a turn and can only attack adjacent pieces. Motherships can move one space or jump into hyperspace from the outer orbit (allowing them to re-enter any space in the outer orbit on a later turn), and they have beam weapons which can attack pieces two or three spaces away. Beam tanks and killer satellites also have beam weapons; beam tanks can only move around the inner orbit and satellites can only jump into hyperspace.

The object of the game is to remove all opposing pieces from the inner orbit.

title: Dioxoid
description:
From the rules:

Dioxoid is a game of chain reactions.  Inside an oxygen molecule, two players bounce their electrons against each other to surround the opponent's nucleus. A single action may cause a reaction that advances or disrupts every electron, changing the entire game.

Description:

Dioxoid is an abstract strategy game. Each player has eight identical pieces which represent electrons. These move one space at a time. When an electron moves adjacent to any other electron, the non-moving electron is repelled and must move away; if it cannot, the moving electron moves away. The repelled electrons may cause others to move, etc. The object is to get all of one's own electrons into the opponent's starting spaces.

title: Dotto
description: The object of the game is to create horizontal, vertical, or diagonal rows of three or more dots of the same color to score the highest possible points.

title: Prospecting
description:
Prospecting is, as might be imagined, a game of prospecting somewhere in the 19th-century American West (the map is not of a real area, although the place names are similar to some found in Montana).

The map is divided into numerous small areas which the players claim and then attempt to find something in.  Every area has a potential number which indicates how likely it is to find something (fertile soil, coal, copper, silver, of gold) there.  Each number has an associated set of outcomes for a 2-dice roll, which in addition to finding something include action cards from the deck, action cards from other players, income, and monetary penalties.  Areas not likely to produce soil, coal, or minerals are more likely to provide cards or income.

Once you find something, you get paid for the claim and that area is done with.  Some things pay better than others, with gold of course paying the most, but this is offset by the fact that making the same strike in an adjacent area will pay double (and a third will double again, etc.), and the less valuable items are easier to find.

Action cards can be used to rob or tax other players, travel faster around the board, squat on someone else's claim, etc.  The take that effect is presumably somewhat reduced by the small hand size (2 in a 4-player game).

The attention to usability in the components is somewhat unusual for a self-published game of this vintage.  Each player gets a calculator which lets you slide a cardboard strip up and down to get the dice-rolling chart for each claim potential (and robbery attempt) individually, instead of having to look it up in a larger chart.  In addition, each calculator has on it a probability table which shows the total percent chance of each possible outcome for each claim potential, and a list of all the action cards and their uses.

title: Hidden Empires
description:
Hidden Empires is a print-and-play game for 2 to 6 players where each player assumes the role of an ant colony.  Players deploy worker ants on an abstracted hex-area map to look for and forage food.  Colonies use food to produce more workers to produce more food, etc.  Eventually colonies grow large enough to produce reproductive male and female ants.  Players score points for each reproductive ant released during a nuptial flight.

A deck of cards provide environmental events and different genetic traits for the various ant species.  Conflict between colonies is possible but is not the primary focus of the game.  All events, traits, and general game play are based on the natural history of actual ant species.

As of 2012 a new version, Hidden Empires II, is available.

title: Sharpsburg
description:
A detailed tactical simulation of the Battle of Antietam.  Uses James Murphy's Battles of the War of the Rebellion rule set.

Published in 1978,  100yds/hex; 15 min./turn. 21 different types of terrain on the TEC. Morale ratings from 11-66. 12 point unit facing and flexible extended line options.  As a result of a morale check a unit can take cover, become shaken, rout, or rout move. Simple but effective command and control rules:  the further a unit from its HQ, the lower its movement allowance.  A unit moving more than half its MA loses firepower during the enemy portion of the turn; if it moves more than its printed allowance (fatigue rules), it can't fire during the enemy portion of the turn.  The game is so detailed, it includes stubble markers for use when Miller's Cornfield is mowed down by fire, and has a beehive rule for use if Mr. Roulette's beehives are smashed by artillery fire.

Designed by Kim Turner, James Murphy, Arthur Mitchell and David Buchbinder.

No other pre-20th Century game has anything like its historical accuracy and richness of detail, John Kisner wrote in a review in 1978, when TSS had a lock on the top spot in SPI's game ratings.  The game is by no means perfect, even disregarding its physical shortcomings, but with its publication, the state of the art in 19th Century tactical games has made as broad and deep an advance as it did with the publication of the original LA BATAILLE DE LA MOSCOWA, he added.

title: Road to Washington
description: Detailed tactical simulation of the Battle of Second Bull Run, using the Battles of the War of Rebellion game system.  The game includes both basic and advanced rules.

title: Scooby-doo Game: Where Are You!
description: The is a simple childrens track game. The track starts at the bottom of the board near the Mystery Machine, continues inside a castle, and has various instructions on certain spaces. The game also includes a spinner used  to determine the number of spaces players can move. The board depicts tunnels and other mysterious places that a player may be taken to. These events are typical of the things that happen in the cartoon.A deck of cards also directs the action of the players. The winner of the game is the first player who follows Scooby and finds the hidden treasure.

title: Tactics: The Military Game
description:
This is an old trick-taking game which incidentally teaches the player the ranks and branches (infantry, cavalry, artillery, engineers) of the military.

Originally published in 1915, it appears to have been bought by Parker Brothers and reissued in 1919 under the name Militac (although the cards still say Tactics on the back).

title: Conundrums
description:
Subtitled: 'An After Dinner Game'

Answers to all questions are words that also relate to food.

title: New Testament The Game of Quotations
description: Cards are won by completing the scripture verses on them.

title: Komical Konversation Kards
description: The Question Cards are printed upon one color, the Answers upon another.  One person draws a Question card and reads it.  Another player draws a card from the Answer pack and reads it.  Much amusement is caused by the comical character of the Questions and Answers.  Almost a Mad-Lib feel to the game.

title: The Game of American History
description: The Game of American History quizzes players on their knowledge of the early history of the United States of America.  Each card in the game features one to three subjects, and each subject is the answer to one to six questions.  The game is played by selecting a card and asking a player one of the questions on it.  If the player gives the right answer, he or she keeps the card.  The winner is the player with the most cards.

title: The All Canadian Trivia Board Game
description: An ordinary trivia game very similar to Trivial Pursuit in its mechanics. There are four categories: general, geography, history and arts. You win the game by collecting a chip for each of these categories. Obviously, all questions are intended for Canadian citizens.

title: Word Wild
description: The object of the game is to create words by adding one letter at a time to the same word as it is passed among the players on sheets of paper as the categories are constantly changed. You score points as you create new words and at the same time try to prevent your opponents from using your word. At the end of play high score wins. And the trick is speed..... you have a timer to keep the game moving along. The game includes a deck of 54 word categories cards, sheets to create words on, a score pad,  and a timer.

title: Word Shaker
description: See how many words you can make in two minutes from the letters on the tiles that spill from the shaker, which is a large ball with a round opening on one side (think of a 'magic 8-ball' that opens).

title: Word Nerd
description:
Play what's on your mind! Word Nerd. A zany new word game. Any number can play this provocative new word game and everyone plays at the same time. Toss the Nerd Cube, pick a letter, and everyone places it where they think they can spell the most 3 and 4 letter words. Letters are worth points and words with the highest points spell victory!

Re-implemented by:

    Spingo (which uses 5-letter German or Swedish words).

title: Stackwords
description: Consists of an 8x8 upright grid into which letter tiles may be dropped at the top of each column. Each column fills from the bottom up. The two players each face a different side of the grid, so what is a legal left-to-right word for one isn't for the other. Only the vertical (top-to-bottom) words are in common. The players score by making words vertically, horizontally or diagonally.

title: Spellbound
description: Letter dice fall into an upright stand which shows letters vertically, on four different sides at once.  Each side requires players to find a different type of word formation.  There are four rapid fire word games including: Free Spell- Find as many words as you can that have 3 letters or more. Chain Words - Write as many words as you can that begin with the last letter of the previous word. First Letter Choice - Pick a letter and find as many words as you can that begin with that letter, and Crosswords - Connect as many words as you can to form a crossword puzzle.

title: Scrabble Got a Minute
description: Seven cubes with red letters (no point values) are encased in a clear 3x3x3 cube  with a minute sand timer. You have 1 minute to find as many words using the 7 letters.

title: Rologram
description: This is a very old game that can be used to play Anagrams and other entertaining games. The game is complete with bright red playing board, 10 marbles, instruction book/score book, and dice cup. The board has 60 holes, each assigned a letter and a number. The marbles are rolled onto the board, and the holes that they land in determine which letters are used to form words.

title: Rätsel Turm
description: The aim of the game is to build towers with coloured blocks, the lowest block representing the first letter of a word, etc. There are blocks of different colours: green means A, B or C; yellow D, E or F, etc. Five different games use this basic system. For example, each player on his turn builds a tower, and the first other player who finds a corresponding word scores 1 point. Another example: The first player chooses a block, and each player on his turn must add a block on the top of the tower, or accuse the former player of bluffing when he cannot name a corresponding word.

title: Tintin et Milou dans le Monde
mechanisms: Card DraftingPoint to Point MovementSimultaneous Action Selection
description:
Tintin e a volta ao mundo (Tintin around the world)

The objective of the game is to cover the circuit between Europe, Oceania and back, bringing back the Treasure of Rackham. The fastest player wins.

By drawing random cards from the deck each player can choose to move his pawn (Tintin), place an obstacle (a bone or a bottle of old rum) or retrieve an obstacle from his way. If the old rum obstacle his placed the player who has it in his lane can only move back to the nearest continent, where he can choose another circuit lane.

title: Triple Flips 5: Police Rescue
description:
Triple Flips 5 includes Kidnap and Rescue, Spy Against Spy, and Runaway School Bus.


     Kidnap and Rescue is a capture-the-flag game for 2-4 players.  Move to the captive, become the captive, and put your own pawn home.  Everyone else continues to try to get the captive, which is now you.  If someone catches you, they become the captive, and you re-enter from home.  Try to get the captive home!



     Spy Against Spy is another intentionally lopsided 2-player game, but this time the effect is a little more like American football.  The defender merely obstructs the offender as much as possible to minimize her progress over the course of ten turns.



     Runaway School Bus is a 1-player timed race, with the interesting twist that the timing is staged.  There are five points along the bus's path where you can intercept it.  You merely need to progress, by die roll of course, along your linear path more quickly than the bus to maximize your score.  This game features a small misprint, since if you don't count the picture of a schoolbus as a space for the bus, getting 5 points is quite literally impossible.  You can't get 14 out of two rolls of a six-sided die - it's low enough odds on three rolls.

title: Triple Flips 6: Sports
description:
Triple Flips 6 includes Championship Boxing, Motorcycle Jumping, and Olympic Biathlon.


     Championship Boxing is a 2-player game in which the players attempt to maneuver about the ring and punch one another when in range.  There are KO spaces along the players' punch tracks by which a player can hope for an early knockout of her opponent.



     Motorcycle Jumping is a 1-player game in which you try to jump as many buses as possible, based on your trajectory and height.  Most of your jump is determined by rolls of the die.



     Olympic Biathlon allows 2-4 players to cross-country ski and shoot their way to victory.  When you get to the shooting range determines the length of the path you take back to the main course once you've shot the target.

title: Triple Flips 8: Auto Racing
description:
Triple Flips 8 includes Indy Pit Stop, Le Mans 24 Hour Race, and Off-Road Challenge Race.


     Indy Pit Stop simulates an Indy 500-style race between 2-4 players.  This is a roll-and-move game with some unusual pitfalls along the track.  Once you have car trouble and have to make a pit stop, you roll a die to determine what the pit crew finds wrong with your car.  1-3 indicates a refueling is in order; 4, tire change; 5, spark plugs; and 6 means it's overheating.  The various problems can take different amounts of time to fix.



     Le Mans 24 Hour Race is a 1-player game.



     Off-Road Challenge Race is a roll-and-move race game with some zany track elements.  Spaces such as Other cars go ahead 4 and Go behind lead car provide unusual interaction of the vehicles.

title: Triple Flips 9: More Sports
description:
Triple Flips 9 includes Sky Diving, Pro Tennis, and Hang Gliding.


     Sky Diving is a 1-player game in which you hope to hit the target accurately.  The closer you are to the target, the better your score.  Your drift during the descent is controlled by die rolls, which indicate the direction of drift.



     Pro Tennis simulates a tennis game for 2 players.  The areas of the court all have corresponding die rolls paired with them.



     Hang Gliding, for 2-4 players, is a roll-and-move game with some branches decided by the roll of a die, and others left up to the player's choice.  The various paths symbolize air currents, including some sharp up-drafts and down-drafts.  The players attempt to maneuver their pawns to the best-scoring landing zones.

title: Triple Flips 10: Disasters
types: American West Animals Dice Science Fiction
description:
Triple Flips 10 includes Outlaw and Stagecoach, Shark Attack, and Alien Invaders From Space.


     Outlaw and Stagecoach is a 2-player game that simulates a Western chase scene, in which the outlaw tries to chase down and rob the stagecoach.  The stagecoach moves one or two spaces (determined by a die roll) along a fixed path toward East City.  The outlaw moves one or two spaces forward or backward, and may utilize the shortcuts.  Once the outlaw ends a move on the same space as the stagecoach, a gunfight occurs.  The gunfight consists of the outlaw winning three out of three rounds of Who can roll a higher number on the die? - re-rolling in the event of a tie.  If the stagecoach wins the gunfight, it escapes with a free move.



     Shark Attack sends 2-4 players diving for treasure in slightly shark-infested waters.  On your turn, you roll a die, then move in orthogonal steps, generally toward the treasure.  You may not swim through other pawns.  If you start your turn in the shark attack zone, which is 4/7 of the playfield, then you will also roll and move the shark.  The shark may swim through other pawns, but if it ends its movement on a player's pawn, that pawn goes back to the boat and starts over.  The goal is not only to get past the shark to reach the treasure, but also return through the shark's waters to the boat thereafter.



     Alien Invaders From Space is a 1-player roll-and-move with a die-driven squad of aliens hunting you along the path.  A die roll indicates which 3-4 of six rooms are occupied by aliens.  For your attempted escape, each turn, you roll a die.  On an even roll, you move that many spaces; odd, the alien in the current room (if any) moves that many spaces, eventually getting into your path and threatening you.  One exception:  If you roll a 1, the aliens all get reset, and you roll again to determine their new three or four starting rooms.  You simply try to reach your rocket ship to Earth without a turn ending you and an alien on the same space.

title: Transat Québec/Saint-Malo
description:
The Transatlantic Race Game

The object of the game is to be the first to complete the race from Qubec (Canada) to Saint-Malo (France). During the race, you try to benefit from the various currents depicted on the board as well as avoiding collisions with icebergs.

title: Varsity: The Scientific Football Game
description: The game comes with a board shaped like a football field with two tracks that the football and 10-yard stick slides up and down, four spinners, dice, and several charts to look up the results of called plays and their results based on the die throws.

title: Queries 'n Theories
description: This game is a simulation of scientific method and generative grammars.  One player invents a language consisting of basic sentences and replacement rules.  The other players attempt to reconstruct the language by astute questioning.

title: Sevastopol
description:
A regimental-level simulation of the British/French siege of the Russian city of Sevastopol during the Crimean War of 1854-1855. Like Lille, it is played on a hexless period map of the fortress and surrounding area, using a provided ruler to determine movement distances.

Part of the Art of Siege quad.

title: Super Sharp Pencil & Paper Games
types: Abstract Strategy Action / Dexterity Book Deduction Educational Math
description:
This pocket book is the American edition of Giocare con Carta e Matita and collects 39 games to be played with paper  pencil (out of the original 50 of the Italian edition). Some of them are traditional, some are invented by more or less famous authors, a couple appear for the first time. A second section with a few strategy and tactics notes is included.

In 2003 the book has been reprinted under the title of Mind-Sharpening Logic Games.

In 2008 an enlarged and revised edition appeared in Italian in 2008 as 101 giochi con carta e matita (ed. Sonda), while a reduced one for children with rewriteable boards has been published in the same year by Editoriale Scienza as Battaglia navale e altri giochi con carta e matita.

title: Finger Hockey
description:
This is a carom style game that incorporates many NHL rules of play. The game board is a simulated hockey rink that comes mounted on a turntable for easy shot access. Each team has five 'player' pieces or wooden disks, and one goalie piece that's loosely attached (off center) to the board allowing it to spin around in the crease. The puck is a small round magnet.

On your turn you get three flicks of your pieces. These can be used to pass the puck to an open player, shoot on goal, or just be a goon and smack your opponents pieces out of position. Be careful. If you're caught offside you might be stuck spending your turn flicking your players back across the blue line.

title: Fishing Frenzy
description:
A sport fishing tournament - whenever and wherever you want it, any time, any place, any weather. Determine the length of the game when you decide on the tournament limit of fish. Play for as little as 15 minutes, or settle into your fighting chair and fish for an hour or more. Leave the dock, fish the channel, and head for open waters. You'll need both strategy and luck to out fish the other boats. The tournament becomes more difficult as each fish is caught and tagged. Beware of the buoys, the shoals, and the Perils of the Sea. They're every angler's nightmare. Points are awarded for the first fish, the most fish, first back to the docks, and for channel, inshore, and offshore slams.

Ages 10 and up. 2 to 6 players. Play it once and you will be hooked.

Game contents: 20' x 30' tri-fold game board, card tray, dice, 6 playing tokens, 100 vinyl tagging squares, 158 fish cards, 11 Peril of the Sea cards, 16 fish stickers, 12 boat stickers, instructions and score sheets. Fish cards feature 15 different brilliantly rendered game fish. Featuring Bertram and Hatteras sport fishing boats.

title: Bumper Golf
description:
Bumper Golf is a deluxe version of the carom golf game, you might play at a Parks and Recreation building. The game board depicts an entire 18-hole golf course. Players shoot their 'balls' (wooden disks) from the numbered tee spots and aim for the equivalent numbered 'hole' (cup depression.)

There are two ways to play. In the first version, each player plays each hole one at a time keeping track of his shots. At the end of 18 holes the player with the fewest strokes wins. For a more interactive game, players alternate taking shots, thus allowing chances to block off holes or knock other players balls out of position. In this version the first player to complete the course is the winner.

title: Florida Saltwater Tournament Fishing
description:
Contents:
Gameboard
Instructions
5 Pawns
1 Six-sided die
29 Game cards (2 Lady Fish, 7 Mako Sharks, 10 Bonefish, 10 Cobia)
54 Tournament Fish cards (9 each worth $300, $200, $100 plus 27 worth $25)
8 Broken Line cards
8 Free Roll cards
Money: 40 each of $25, $50, $100 and $500

title: Dizzy Spell
description: The board is 5x5 with holes which are initially covered with reversible O/X pieces, all on the O side. Then a card with letters which align with the holes is inserted in the base. The first player uncovers two letters, making sure his opponent sees them too, then replaces the plugs, X side up. Play continues with the players alternating. After the third pair of letters has been revealed, each player may guess a word every turn. To do so, announce the word, then expose the letters (from the Xs) in the correct order. If correct, the player keeps the pieces removed and those letters can no longer be used. If incorrect, remove 2 points from the guesser's score. Once all letters are X side up, continue the process but flip the pieces back to the O side. Play continues until all the pieces are back to the O side or both players decide to give up. Score 1 point per piece.

title: Kameltreiber AG
description:
Camel racing meets memory. Players set up a racing track consisting of 25 tiles. Every player gets a camel. Movement is made by turning over one of 36 hidden tiles numbered 1-6 (using the tile that the previous player turned over is not allowed). Depending on the space you land on you may move again, must end your turn or go to the end of the caravan. Overlapped camels are out of the race. Last camel in wins.

Mainly a memory game with some nice racing elements in it.

title: Russia at War
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
This is an expansion for Xeno Games' Europe at War.

The Russia at War expansion includes :


    New charts and set up for a 1941 starting time.
    Additional Russian playing pieces.
    Additional German and Italian playing pieces.
    Additional playing pieces used for partisans and Neutral Countries.
    Printed play money and additional mini-chips.


Expands:

    Europe at War

title: Triple Flips 4: Sci-Fiction
description:
Triple Flips 4 includes Save the Earth, Time Warp, and Robot Attack.


     Save the Earth is a 1-player game that seems to be inspired by Missile Command.  Four missiles are bearing down on Earth, and you make straight, orthogonal moves based on the die roll, trying to hit the missiles before they reach Earth.  Each turn, the missiles advance - although, if you are blocking a missile's path downward, it will wait until you are out of the way to advance.  You essentially have 9 turns to fly around frantically to destroy the four missiles - well, 7 for two of them.



     Time Warp is a simple elimination game for 2-4 players, comprising two concentric, rectangular tracks - past and future - interconnected at four points by time machines.  That is the gimmick.  Roll, then move one way or the other, trying to land on an opponent to eliminate her.  If you land on a time machine, you may use it to switch tracks and go again.



     Robot Attack is a 2-player game, which seems related to Hnefatafl.  One player tries to traverse the passageways, by orthogonal moves from her die roll, to her spaceship, which conveniently lies behind the opponent's four robots.  The robot player tries to trap the other player with his robots, by splitting each roll among however many robots he wishes.  Not only are the robots inherently  the speed of the spaceman, but they also are unable to move backward, toward the ship.  As a result, the robot player must be attentive in his move choices.  Fortunately for him, most of the board has four or fewer chokepoints to cover at any given vertical slice; unfortunately, players are neither allowed to waste pips from their die roll, nor retread a space on the same turn.

title: Adultery
description: From the rules: The object of the game is spend a good time with 2 different players of the opposite sex.  NOTE: Drinks  Mixes should be close at hand.  Players spin and move their game piece around the board getting tokens worth two, three and five minutes.  When all players have three time tokens, players are selected at random to retire to another part of the house.  Game ends when each player had the chance to spend time in private with two different players.

title: Air Trix
mechanisms: Pick-up and DeliverPoint to Point Movement
description: Race against the clock to score points in this fascinating jet stream action game.  Maneuver the ball on a cushion of air through the rungs of the ladder, onto to barrel on the seal's nose, through the weather vane into the bucket and finally into the helicopter cockpit to pick up the mail.  You score points for each stunt.  The player with the highest score wins.

title: Balaroo
types: Action / Dexterity Electronic Humor Party Game
description: The game board is a motorized, rotating platform with twelve colored spaces and a swing arm with a wrecker ball at the end.  Players bet on how long their piece will remain standing with points awarded for win, place or show, but in the end, the last player standing is the winner.

title: Bang Box
description: Inflate a number of balloons equal to one less than the total number of players and place them under the Bang Box.  Each player on their turn spins the spinner and must drive that number of nails into any holes of their choice without busting a balloon.  When a player bursts a balloon that player is out of the game.  The remaining players continue until there is only one player left, the winner!

title: Great Alaskan Clean-Up
description:
From the introduction:

Just suppose that there is an Oil Company, and it's called EX-CON. And suppose that it has tankers cruising all around the world, delivering oil. And suppose that one of these tankers is sailing around off the coast of Alaska. And just suppose the captain can't hold his liquor and has headed back to his cabin to sleep it off. And just suppose that the guy in charge of swabbing the deck is now piloting the ship and he accidentally hits a reef with the ship and spills oil all over the coast of Alaska. This situation is, of course, theoretical. But if this did happen, then you'd have... THE GREAT ALASKAN CLEAN-UP

title: Triple Flips 1: Horses
description:
Triple Flips 1 includes Steeplechase Championships, Ride-em Cowboy, and Ride the High Country.


     Steeplechase Championships, for 2-4 players, uses a linear path of obstacles, each labeled with the rolls (on two dice) required to pass it.  For instance, to start, you need to roll 2-5; then to clear the water jump, 6-9; then for the brick wall, 10-12.  To clear the logs at the end, you need to roll doubles.



     Ride-em Cowboy (a rodeo game for 1-4 players) is a game in which it is appropriately difficult to score well.  Appropriately for simulating a rodeo, players often won't stay on the bronco long enough to score, but, on the other hand, occasionally someone will ride the whole way out.



     Ride the High Country is just a basic roll-and-move game for 2-4 players.

title: Triple Flips 2: Monsters
description:
Triple Flips 2 includes Curse of the Pyramid, Vampire Attack, and Escape the Evil Castle.


     Curse of the Pyramid is a race game for 1 player.  You mark half the dice numbers as belonging to the mummy, then roll the die.  If the mummy's numbers get rolled, he moves toward the goal; if not, then you move the actual number rolled.  Of course, your path is substantially longer than his.  You also are required to change the mummy's numbers each turn.



     Vampire Attack lets 2-4 players attempt to bite each other.  On your turn, roll the die, then move orthogonally with up to one 90 turn per move, in an attempt to sidle up to another player.  Once you get orthogonally adjacent to an opponent, roll again.  A 1 (appropriately, the big, red pip) means you've bitten them and they're out of the game.



     Escape the Evil Castle is a spiteful race game for 2-4 players.  Players traverse a linear path toward the goal, advancing the roll of a die each turn.  However, your roll also moves Dracula, whom you can move in either direction.  If you move Dracula onto an opponent, she must move her pawn back to the 0%, 25%, 50%, or 75% mark.

title: Playmobil: Alarm! Alarm!
description:
Goal is to get rid of your own cards as fast as possible. First the table cards are laid out - leaving space in between for other cards. The other cards are dealt out. The active player can play up to three cards placing them along one of the table cards with a suitable motive. If a player can't place any cards he has to pass. Table cards with four played cards are removed from the game and the surrounding cards are dealt to the one who last placed a card. Winner is the player with the least cards who didn't have to pass.

Es gilt, seine Handkarten mglichst gut abzuspielen.
Am Anfang werden die Tischkarten im Zentrum offen ausgelegt. Dabei sollte zwischen den Karten so viel Platz bleiben, da man an jede Kante eine Karte legen kann.
Die Spielkarten werden grndlich gemischt und dann an die

title: Alles in Ordnung
description: Goal is to collect the most toys (cards) of one category. First 16 cards are laid out face down into a 4x4 grid. The remaining cards become the draw pile. The players choose a figure and place it next to one of the laid out cards. The active player throws the die and moves his figure along the side of the field - in the direction he chooses. The player may than turn around as many cards in a row as allowed by the die - the cards remain face up till the end of the game. He may take one card replacing it with a card from the draw pile - face down. The game ends as soon as the draw pile is exhausted.

title: Badetag
description: Each player draws two tiles. The remaining tiles are placed face down on the table. Each player also receives 5 stripes face up depicting a dirty figure with a clean side face down. Every a turn a player selects a tile. If he got a tile with the picture of a flannel he has to turn one stripe of his figure from the dirty side to the clean side. Otherwise he looks whether he now has a trio of motives or background colors. If so,  he keeps the trio and draws another two tiles. As soon as one figure of any player is perfectly clean the game ends and the one with the most trios wins.

title: Don't Miss the Boat
types: Action / Dexterity Children's Game Humor Memory Nautical
description:
CONTENTS
yellow island, yellow cone
8 balls on strings
8 boats
4x 3playing pieces, dice

OBJECT OF THE GAME
to be the first player to get all three playing pieces onto the island.

HOW TO PLAY
Each player takes 3 playing pieces of one color and places them in any 3 separate boats. At the start not more than 2 men per boat.
During the game not more than 3 men per boat are allowed.
Each player in turn, throws the dice and moves any one of his men from boat to boat. A player must also select a ball from the central cone to pull in one of the boats.
If the boat pulled ashore contains the player's own play piece then he may place it on the island. If the place on the island is already occupied by an opponent's piece then the play pieces are exchanged.

title: Dabol
description:
The game from Johann Cruyff. Dabol recreates a football game tactically. There is a Die for each player, you can create teams selecting dices from 1 to 16. Each Die has a variable values. The values represent pass, movement, kick and defense. The ball is placed in the field through the different areas of play.

The field is divided in 8 parts each representing the playing areas in a soccer field.

The rules are simple but at the same time with a lot of tactical options. It is a rare game published at the end of 20th century.

title: Sentence Says
types: Card Game Educational Humor Party Game Word Game
description:
The components of Sentence Says are:  4 sets of oversized cards: vowel cards, consonant cards, action cards and steal cards, 4 oversized sand timers: 15, 30, 45, and 60 seconds and 1 oversized custom die.

The object of Sentence Says is to create a sentence out of letter cards that you are dealt, using each letter as the first letter of a word of your choice.  For example, the letter C could become Cat, Could or any word that you choose beginning with the letter C.

So, if you were dealt a hand consisting of the letters:  M,F,G,A,B,P, you could create the sentence: Freddy's Billy Goat Ate Pancakes Monday...or Get Powder Because My Foot Aches!.  You can arrange the cards in any order to create your sentence.  But you are under a time limit and the time depends on how many cards you are dealt (anywhere from 5-7 depending on the roll of the die).  There is also an action card that you must draw before turning over your cards.  The action cards give you an instruction for completing your sentence, such as Your sentence must be in the form of a question or Do not use a proper name.

Points are at the bottom of every card.  You accumulate points by creating an acceptable sentence within the time limit.  You can also wager points by stealing when an opponent misses a sentence.

The fun of the game is coming up with well thought-out sentences and hearing the silly sentences that people try to get away with (and of course, winning).  It's perfect to play a one on one session or in a large group at a party.

Sentence Says is brand new game and is available at select specialty retail outlets or online at www.sentencesays.com

title: Families in Nature
description:
Discover the most fascinating inhabitants on Earth!  A card game unlike any other, which combines comical illustrations and multiple choice questions. Players will discover and understand the relationship between creatures and their natural habitats.

Game Principles and Objectives : Collect the animal and plant species (birds, flowers...) living in identical natural habitats (tropical forests, deserts...). To get a card, players must guess which player has the desired card and also answer the question correctly. Answers are fully explained and illustrated.

title: Life in Colonial Williamsburg
description: Step back in time! This exciting game is a virtual visit to Williamsburg. First, choose one of eight characters: merchants, milliner, tavern keeper, slave... Then, with the roll of a die, explore the colonial capital. Stop at points of interest, experience everyday and historic events and collect Colonial LifeTokens along the way. The first to collect all seven wins! Category cards--Meet the People, Colonial Events and Pages in History--add spice to the game with questions and commands. Be careful--you might wind up in the stocks, or even on trial at the Capital. Three levels of play; great fun for Ages 8 and up.

title: The American Girls Collection Card Game
description: Have fun while learning more about the American Girls with this rummy-style card game. The deck of 64 cards features full-color illustrations from the stories of all eight American Girls.

title: Pro Football
description: Simple American Football game using spinners to determine the types of plays and reactions.  Very random game-play with little strategy.  Not to be confused with 3M's 1966 game of the same title or the 1969 Chapman Pro Football.

title: 3-A-Side
description:
From the box: Strike for goal in this simple game of tactics which is easy to learn and fun to play.

An abstract strategy game with a soccer theme.  Strategically move your pieces to score a goal off your opponent.

title: New York Scene
description:
From the back:

The excitement of Broadway, a shopping spree along Fifth Avenue, elegant dining among the skyscrapers of Manhattan, and a tour of the city's famous landmarks - all these are a part of the New York Scene.

Have you ever wanted to own the Mets, Tiffany's, the Plaza Hotel or the Daily News?  Now is your chance by playing the New York Scene!

- you will buy and sell your favorite local properties;

- become either a union leader, a lawyer, a politician, or a network executive;

- bargain with the other players to receive a Connection Card which will permit you to develop your properties and thereby collect increased rent.

The object of the New York Scene is to accumulate wealth and enjoy a unique witty and up-to-date view of the exciting way of life in New York.  During the Game you will draw New York Scene Cards which will reward or penalize - for example:

-- The Aussie Strikes Again - You may Buy Any or All of the Newspapers for Twice Their Stated Purchase Price

-- You're Riding the Subway, the Hand in Your Pocket Belongs to Someone Else - Lose Two Turns Due to Shock

title: Monopoly: Corvette
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock HoldingTrading
description:
From the back of the box:
Shift into high gear with 50 years of your favorite corvette models.  Experience the thrill of owning the most collectible Corvette cars ever produced.

The Corvette debuted in 1953 at the General Motors Motorama at New York's posh Waldorf Astoria and has since become the uncontested master of the American-made sports car. The MONOPOLY Brand proudly introduces a game designed exclusively for the dedicated Corvette collector.  Featuring 50 years of celebrated vintage shark coupes, classic Sting Ray convertibles and the limited edition 50th Anniversary, this version of the world's most famous board game puts you right in the driver's seat.

Fuel your Corvette passion -- play this high performance edition of the MONOPOLY game and leave the competition in the dust.

title: Triple Four
description:
From the publisher:
It's FUN- times 3 -when you play this exciting family card game! Match three of your playing cards to a Triplet card. And don't forget...Jokers are WILD! Be the first to collect four groups of matching cards and you win the game! With a little strategy and the luck of the draw, you could score a TRIPLE FOUR! It's three times the fun for the whole family.

CONTENTS: 
2 DECKS PLAYING CARDS 
1 DECK TRIPLET CARDS 
4 CUSTOM CARD TRAYS 
GAME INSTRUCTIONS

title: How Tall am I?
description:
Players roll the die to get various body parts. Each character is built up of a hat, a head, arms, body and feet. The various body parts has different hight, and the object is to collect 5 different parts to build the tallest character.

Ages 3 - 8
Game components: Thirty character parts, custom measuring ruler, one die

title: Thunder Ball
mechanisms: Area MovementPick-up and DeliverVariable Player Powers
description: Thunder Ball is The Game of Jammin' Hoops and Explosive Magic. A limited number of points are assigned various player skills - Shoot, Steal, Catch, Block and Intelligence - and then the NBA meets Harry Potter and arena combat in a fantasy basketball game to 10 points (five successful shots on the basket of your color on the hexagonal mapboard). Players are allowed two actions per turn with die rolls (augmented by player skill points) determining the success of actions ranging from shooting for a basket to using spell cards.

title: Andantino
description:
In Andantino, a game from the inventor of Trax, two players take turns placing hexagonal tiles in their own color. To start, one tile of each color are placed together on the table. Each tile placed must touch at least two pieces already in play. (Although a variant allows the second player to place one tile next to only one other tile to balance a first-player advantage.) A player wins by surrounding at least one of the opponent's tiles with tiles of his own color or by creating a line of five tiles of his own color.

Since the tiles placed are never moved, this game can alternatively be played on hexagonal paper with the players using pens of two colors.

title: 2-Handed Whammy!
description: A Rummy variant played with a deck of 220 cards where the object is to collect number sets and go out (empty your hand). Special cards include: Wild, Bonus and Whammy! Instructions include rules for individual and partnership play.

title: Out of Control
description: Played with a deck of 92 cards (two sets of cards numbered 1-10 in four colors, along with 12 wild cards), the object of Out of Control is to be first to complete a succession of cards from 1 to 10 in ascending order in a single color. A six-color die adds the twists to the game, with each color on the die representing a different instruction/action (such as take a card from another player and add it to your hand).

title: ITV Seven
description:
For the famous Saturday afternoon sports programe 'World of Sport'
A great game of betting on the horses. Seven races and you bet on the all the one with the most money wins.
You draw 7 cards form a stanard pack and odds are worked out from the 7 cards (chart in the box shows the odds based on the cards). Player bet on one of the four siuts depending on the odds. Cards are trun over one at at time from the pack and for each suit turned over the horse one one place forward. First horse across the line wins.
Easy to play and great fun for 2 to as many as you like.

title: Dixon of Dock Green
description:
For the classic 1950/60's UK TV program. 
Cops and Robbers board game. 
Can  you get the bad guy before he makes it to the airport and skips the country.

title: Polémique
description:
Party game where controversy (polmique) is inherent, welcome and, even, provoked.

Each player is given three cards: one I agree, one I disagree and one question mark card.

In turn, each player draws an affirmation card, reads it aloud and tells everyone if (s)he is in agreement with it, paying attention to the other players' reaction. Then, each player choose, without lying, the card that describes best his opinion of the affirmation (I agree or I disagree). The question mark card is used to hide the chosen card. The player who read the card then choose three players and tries to guess their opinion. Each good guess earns him one token.

title: That's Incredible!
types: Card Game Math Memory Movies / TV / Radio theme Party Game Word Game
description:
The game deck consists of eighty-one cards. Each card has a letter of the alphabet, a slot machine symbol, a number between one and twenty-six and is one of four colors. The game comes with instructions to play nine games with the deck. Dice and a game pad complete the package.

Zenith  A crossword game.
Beat the Bandit  The dealer accepts bets and pays the punters for certain slot machine symbol combinations.
Thats Incredible!  A memory game that uses the colors on the cards.
Castaways  The players use the cards dealt to them to calculate a target number determined by the dealer.
Sequence 26  A memory game that uses the letters on the cards.
Corner Bank  Players score for remembering combinations of colors.
Preposterous  Players score for remembering sequences of numbers.
Unravel  The dealer selects a secret combination of colors and the other player must deduce the combination by making guesses.
Shootout  The colors have rank and the player who reveals the highest ranked card during a round wins all cards of all the other players.

The rules give a post office box and a toll-free telephone number to encourage players to contact the publisher with game results. The game is a promotional tie-in to a popular television series of the eighties.

title: Word-Wise
description: Each card contains a consonant. A player can just declare any vowels needed. The players must construct words using the cards dealt to them. Handicapping rules allow players of unequal skill levels to compete.

title: Carnage
description:
Carnage is a fantasy table-top miniatures wargame depicting a war between human barbarians and humanoid lizard people called Herptars.

The game is typical of 25mm scale fantasy wargames and involves archers, cavalry, infantry and magic-wielding sorcerers for both forces.  Carnage introduces certain elements of humor to keep the game light-hearted.  A good deal of this game's audience is the convention going crowd and the designers purposely implemented tongue-in-cheek silliness to keep the game in perspective.

At the heart of the carnage battlefield is a reality-altering orb drawn along in a cart by two flamingo-dodoes.  The cart skips around the battlefield during the game causing random effects that help, hinder, annoy and amuse both sides.  Effects range from rain showers to muddy the ground and slow opponents to random teleportations.  Everything is all in the spirit of fun.

Overall, Carnage is a good, non-serious wargame that still requires some strategy to win.

title: Tributary: A Supplement to Source of the Nile
description:
Expansion for the Discovery Games edition of Source of the Nile.

This supplement clarifies many rules from Source of the Nile, and introduces many new and optional rules including:

    customizing not only the explorer but EVERY guide, bearer and askari with individual skills, stregnths, and weaknesses
    rules for lady explorers
    rules for developments in weapon technology, to even up the odds against the heathen savages
    rules for the slave trade, and encounters with slave raiders
    cape colony and the Boers
    rules for shooting the rapids and going over cataracts
    a name generator for tribes.




While this supplement was intended for the discovery games edition, with a little tweaking, it is serviceable for use with the Avalon Hill edition, particularly if you use the game 2 ruleset. Using all of these rules will greatly increase the complexity of the game, but if you can handle it all, it is a very rewarding and involved simulation of an African adventure.

title: High Risk!
mechanisms: Campaign / Battle Card DrivenPoint to Point MovementVariable Player Powers
description:
HIGH RISK ! captures all the feel of international struggle - political, economic, military - and translates it into an exciting, realistic and very playable simulation that puts you at the helm of State! Assuming the role of both national leader and representative of a world ideology, you strive with other players for global domination, compete for scarce resources, make (or break!) treaties, mobilize for war or become an industrial giant! Countless opportunities - and threats - confront you and challenge your skill as a diplomat, economist and general.

HIGH RISK ! is for those who aren't afraid to play for big stakes! Whether through negotiation, bluff, treachery or just sheer force, you've got to beat the odds and the competition in order to rise to the position of WORLD LEADER!

Basic version includes a 24x36 4 color map, over 500 plastic counters, 3 types of playing cards and various other player aids.

title: Clickety-Clak
description: A children's game in which marbles are dropped down a chute on to the playing surface.  Players score points according to where the marbles land on the board.

title: Buckshot!
description: One player has a puck and stick.  The other players try to defend by sliding a plastic piece back and forth in front of their goals.  A very fast moving, hockey-like game.

title: El Dorado
description: Game of logic, similar to Parker Brother's Black Box.  Players try to determine the location of treasure by asking astute questions.

title: Color Clowns
description:
A game of Creating and Matching Colours.

2-4 Players ages 4-7 (front of box) or 5-8 (back of box!)

Game Contents:
o 4 playing boards
o 36 translucent tiles in 3 geometric shapes and 3 colors
o 2 special playing dice, one showing shapes and the other colors

Object of the Game:
To be the first to change the colors of the clowns to green, orange and purple.

How to Play:
o Each player, in turn, rolls the dice
o Player must then place a tile matching the shape on the die on a similar shape of a clown on the board so that the color now created on the board matches both the color rolled on the other die and the frame surrounding the clown.

Example: 1st die Triangle - 2nd Die Green

Player may either place a yellow triangular tile on a blue triangle on the board, or a blue triangular tile on a yellow triangle.  Each will create the colour green.

title: The Dragon and the Pearl
description:
The Dragon and the Pearl is, essentially, the Britannia game concept set in China during the same era. The succession of invading hordes arrive historically accurately, but points are rewarded for surviving rather than being in the right place at the right time, so strange and interesting results are possible. A  full historical background is provided so you can try to get it right if you want to, the dice-based combat system has a fair element of chance to stop it getting too serious.

Re-implements:

    Britannia

title: Tabaijana: Flucht von der Feuerinsel
description:
It's a cooperative game for 2-5 players, which can be played in two forms (a simpler one and a harder one). It's goal is to rearrange crates of different colors by moving them in stacks. The ultimate goal is to reach a sorted stack before the ship has to leave the island (symbolized by 24 spaces on the map), which is the background story of the game: a volcano has erupted on an inhabited island and now all people on this island have to work together to gather as much resources, which is represented with the crates, to start a new life somewhere else.

Ages 5 and up

title: Malaika
description:
Malaika ... a pure abstract strategy board game for 2 players.

Played with 15 glass stones each on a hexagonal board that is divided into 96 triangles of 2 different colours.

Players may only move their stones forwards or sideways on their own 48 colour triangles.

Stones reaching the opposite side of the board are returned to and continue from the original back row start position.

It is a game of movement and capture by surrounding the opponent's stones and removing them from the board.

All possible captures must be made until a player, who has only 1 stone left, concedes defeat.

title: Trivial Detective
description:
From the back of the box:

Hey, listen up! If you like trivia games and you like detective games, then Trivial Detective is for you. The questions in this game are harder than the questions in most trivia games, but in this game you can travel around the board picking up clues to help you figure out the answers.

Many of the clues are also in the form of trivia questions, so the more trivia you know, the easier it will be for you to interpret the clues and win the game. You'll find clues at twelve locations around the board including the library, city hall, movie theater, sports arena, radio  TV station, art museum, museum of natural science, and the geographical  historical society.

Includes: 6 sided die, 6 pawns, game board, game cards, quiz booklet, checklist pad, and clue and answer booklet.

title: Logomachy
description: Logomachy plays like Casino with words: players in their turn either combine one card from the hand with cards on the table to make words, or add a card from the hand to the pool. At the end of the hand, one scores 3 points for taking the most cards, 1 for each Prize card, 2 for each Double Prize card, and 1 for each sweep (a sweep is if you remove all the cards currently on the table during your turn).

title: Thorns
description:
Thorns is a variant on the game Hex. The gameboard is made up of Thorns, which are squares with triangles on each side. The squares and triangles are arranged in a grid.

Players alternate turns. Each turn, a player marks one of the squares with their symbol (X or O) and draws a line through the square and into two of the triangles on opposite sides. This creates a thorn. The players are attempting to create a continuous path of thorns from one side of the board to another. Thorns are considered touching if they touch or if their triangles overlap

The first player to create a continuous path from one side of the board to the other is the winner.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.

title: Nab
description:
Another of 3M's 'Paper Games', Nab consists of 15 circles arranged in a triangular pattern. The players take turns drawing lines through from 1 to 5 circles. All of the circles in the line must be in a straight line with each other and cannot have been marked through previously. The player who is forced to draw the line through the last unmarked circle loses.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.

title: Hedron
description:
Hedron is played on a board representing an opened dodecahedron (12 sided surface) which forms 12 five-sided areas. (the outside of the figure is the 12th area). The players take turns placing an X or an O on one of the lines of the figure. Whoever puts marks on three or more sides of an area controls that area and gets the points for that area (printed inside). Whoever puts marks on three or more of the border sides gets the points for the 12th area. The player with the most points wins.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.

title: Plasm
description:
Plasm is played on a grid of pentagons. Scattered among the pentagons are a series of two, three and five pointed shapes which are shaded.

The players take turns making either an X or an O in the pentagons. Their first move can be anywhere, but subsequent moves must be connected to a pentagon which they have already claimed.

Points are scored by surrounding the shaded areas. The player who claims the last pentagon surrounding the shaded area claims it by putting their mark inside the area. Shaded areas are scored by the number of points they have.

Play continues until all of the shaded areas have been claimed. The player with the highest point total wins.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.

title: Snare
description:
Snare is played on a grid resembling a checkerboard. Half of the squares are shaded and contain a circle, the others are blank.

Players alternate turns. Each turn, a player marks an X in any unshaded square on the board. When a move is made which completely surrounds one or more of the shaded squares, the player making the move marks all of the circles as belonging to him.

Players continue to alternate moves until all shaded squares have been captured. The player capturing the most shaded squares is the winner.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.

title: Quizzle
description: Quizzle contains four plastic crossword grids, a supply of cardboard letter tiles (also wild blanks and black squares) and a special die marked (1 1 2 2 3 *). On a player's turn, he rolls the die and places that many letters of his choice on the grid (other players simultaneously draw the same tiles but place them on their own grids as they choose). A Joker (*) counts for either 3 tiles or the replacement of an already-played tile. The game ends once the grid is filled. Only completed words count for score.

title: Corrida no Hípodromo
description: Corrida no Hpodromo (Hippodrome racing) - Luck in rolling the wheel and the strategy in using the race cards in favor of another horse determine how the race goes - high speed stages mixture themselves with the intermittent presence of obstacles. The winning player is the one that placed his bets on the winning horses.

title: Doubletaire
description:
From the box:
Doubletaire(tm) is the fast action card game for two players.  Based on the classic game of Solitaire, players must race to play as many cards as possible before the game is stopped.  Extra freeze and undo cards have been added to keep the game exciting and unpredictable.  The game is perfect for Ages 7 and up.  Winning at Doubletaire (tm) requires a combination of speed and strategy... and maybe a little luck.

title: Golden Trivia Cards: National Football League (NFL) Edition
types: Card Game Expansion for Base-game Memory Sports Trivia
description:
NFL themed trivia game from the mid-80's.  Be sure you know your NFL facts to get these questions correct.


    What is Miami's home stadium?
    Who is the Colts' all-time rushing leader?
    Name three 1983 NFL coaches who were former NFL quarterbacks.
    What Super Bowl was the first played on artificial turf?
    Name two of the three players who have scored six touchdowns in a game.


These are samples of some of the questions. Just remember when you play... the game was published in 1984.

title: Minitar
description:
While Minitar has an ostensible political theme (the 1968 US presidential election), in fact it is a completely abstract game.

Each player has a deck of cards depicting the 50 states and Washington DC, plus a wild card.  On a turn a player draws a card and places it on the 8x8 board.  If it is the first card played in one of the rows in the player's half of the board, it can go anywhere in that row, otherwise it must be adjacent to one of his or her already-placed cards.  In addition, a card can be played on top of the opponent's card showing the same state (and the wild card can be played on top of any card).

The object is to connect the two ends of the board with a chain of cards in your color.  Whoever manages this gets points equal to the number of electoral votes for the states in the chain.  A match is won by the first player to reach 538 points.  It is also possible to win a game by making it impossible for the other player to move.

As the rules are quite simple, most of the 28-page rulebook is taken up by background information - on the US as it was in the 1960 census, politicians holding office in the states and the federal government, the 1956, 1960, and 1964 elections, etc.

title: Mighty Trees
description:
An educational collectible card game that is built around the competition of trees for resources in order to dominate in the canopy.  In the course of the game, you must deal with the natural disasters, sunlight, and combat with other trees.  Painstakingly researched, the game is exceedingly detailed and amusingly illustrated.

Each deck consists of the same 100 cards, which is all you need to play--though a second deck adds a little variety.  There are rules for three levels of games (seedling, timber, and elder stage) that slowly introduce all of the mechanics.

You can get more information and order at
http://mightytrees.weebly.com/
OR
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Mighty-Trees-Card-Game/199342063442808

title: Ice Cream Scoops of Fun
description:
The object of the game is to be the player with the most ice cream in their bowl when the game is over.  Players have Ice Cream Sunday cups with 3 flavors of ice cream and various toppings in front of them with a group of ice cream cards in the middle.  In turn, the players pull an ice cream card and click the included scoop which will show either chocolate, vanilla, or strawberry.  Whichever player has the Ice Cream Sunday cup with the flavor just spun and the topping matching the ice cream card gets the ice cream card in his bowl.  Keep doing this until all of the ice cream cards are taken.

Basically, this a game where you are trying to match patterns.  The ice cream scoop randomizer is one of the more interesting randomizer methods in a game.

title: The Battle of Balaclava
description:
While the rules call this a wargame, it is highly abstract and more of a family game.

The system is an interesting attempt at representing the general flow of a given battle with very simple rules.  The board consists of a (very sketchy) schematic of the battle area overlaid with arrows indicating the troop movements, much as one might see on a diagram of a battle.

The arrows are divided into spaces - on a turn, a player rolls a die and moves a piece (infantry or cavalry - the artillery does not move) along the appropriate arrow (which arrow or arrows it can use depends on where it starts).  Landing on certain spaces may let you advance further, or may destroy the piece (there are a number of the latter spaces on the Light Brigade's paths).  Getting to the end of an arrow destroys an enemy piece, generally, but sometimes has other effects on the opponent.

There are special rules for each group indicating what its orders are or what it actually did in the battle, more or less (some can traverse the arrows more than once, etc.).

While the box says that either 2 or 4 people can play, there is no provision in the rules for more than 2, and no obvious way to accommodate this.

Greensmith designed a similar game for Palitoy on the battle of Waterloo.

title: The Dukes of Hazzard Card Game
types: Card Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
This is basically a rummy game, with some pieces of Uno (from the makers of Uno), and the Dukes of Hazzard theme pasted on.  Melds are of at least 3 good guy together, 3 bad guys together, or 3 of the same character and are obligatory if possible.  You can add to your own melds and do not have to discard in going out.  There are also some special cards, played as discards, to make it interesting:

Road Block -- Reverse direction and take another turn
Speed Trap -- Next player loses a turn
Parking Ticket -- Next player draws 2, cannot meld or discard
Hazzard County Clout -- Played in response to last 2 cards, reverses effects onto the original player.  No effect if simply discarded.
Hogg Wild -- Next player draws four, cannot meld or discard.

None of these special cards can be picked up from the discard pile except a Hazzard County Clout that has been discarded.  Scoring is the same as rummy, with a 50 point bonus for going out.  First player to 500 wins.

title: Color Train Game
description:
Discovery Toys edition:
Cubes are placed randomly on the inside track of the game board. The die is placed under the train, and the train is moved along the track. If the die matched the corresponding cube when the train is stopped, the player may take the cube and place it on their board. A black dot is another turn, and a star is wild.

Chateau edition:
Each player is trying to collect one passenger from each of four colors in his train car.  One of each color passenger is waiting at each of four colored passenger stations.  Each turn a player chooses a station to go to and pushes the train around the track to that station.  Inside the engine is a pop-o-matic die that pops as you move the train.  At the station, you may pick up a passenger that matches the color of the die if one is available and you do not already have a passenger of that color.  A white spot allows you to choose any present passenger you do not already have and a black spot prevents you from taking any passenger.

title: Care Bears: On the Path to Care-a-Lot
description: Each player starts with a different combination of star chips with pictures that match the bellies of various bears.  Each turn you spin the spinner, and everyone who has a chip with that symbol may play one on their row of stars.  When you complete your row of stars, you then move up the stars toward Care-a-Lot, but only one space at a time whenever someone spins that next space.  The first player to Tender Heart Bear in Care-a-Lot is the winner!

title: Strawberry Shortcake in Big Apple City
description: You are trying to be the first player to go to the bake-off and make it back to the Strawberry House.  Each turn you spin the spinner and move to the next space of the color indicated.  But watch out for the Peculiar Purple Pieman from Porcupine Peak!  If you land on one of his spaces, you will have to pick a pie or two and hope it is not his -- or you have to go back to a purple space.

title: Noah's Ark
description: Each player has a selection of animals they are trying to get into the Ark.  On each turn, spin the spinner.  There are spaces with two different animals that allow you to place one of those animals in the ark if you have one.  If you spin the blank space, you put nothing in the ark.  The first player to get all of their animals in the ark wins!

title: MacDonald's Farm Game
description:
Four Scotch brothers, Sandy, Neil, jack and Rob MacDonald, own four adjourning farms.  But they have no livestock, no poultry, not even a dog for their farms.  They can get what they need at the County fair, but because the supp of each item is limited as e each brother wants to be the FIRST to stock his farm, the competition is keen and exciting.  In playing MacDonald's Farm Game, you can take the part of one of the Scotch brothers and attempt by Selecting Stock at the County Fair -- Cornering the Market -- Trading and Unloading Surpluses to be the FIRST to stock up your own farm.

Each player tries to fill his farm with the exact animals needed. On each turn, you spin the spinner and must take one group of animals, if possible, from the section the spinner lands on.  If you have too many of a specific animal, you may attempt to trade by spinning.  If the spinner lands on a trade space, you may attempt to negotiate a single trade with any of your opponents.  Otherwise, your turn ends.  Once you have all of your needed animals, you get rid of your excess at the county fair.  Again, you spin and if you land on a county fair space, you may return one group listed there to the stock.  Otherwise your turn ends.  However, if you forget to declare that you are going to the fair, you must draw animals as though it were a normal turn.

title: Riot Act
description: From Publisher Website:  This Act-Up, Act-Out, Action game is a REVOLUTIONARY new way to play Charades! Players must act out what is described on the Act card, in whatever manner the Riot deck tells them. The Riot cards range from a simple adverb, to combining your action with some bizarre task not seen everyday. For example, you might be asked to Milk a cow... FORGETFULLY. Or, you may have to Change a baby's diaper... WHILE BEING CHASED BY KILLER BEES. To win at Riot Act, be the first team to reach the center of the board... LOVINGLY... WALKING ON HOT COALS!

title: Combat Zone
description: Combat Zone is a tabletop miniatures skirmish game in 25mm scale.  CZ is set in an alternate near future where corporations have walled off cities to protect their economic interests.  Economies have crumbled as corporations have turned to military warfare as a means of assuring their financial futures.  Destitute gangs, corporate para-military and combat robots all take part in battles to scratch out an existence in this Mad Max-esque world.

title: Généric
description: In this French party game about the cinema, each team tries to make a movie by collecting cards (actor, actress, director, scenario, set and advertisement). This is done by different means : finding movie titles containing a particular word, guessing the music hummed by your teammate, guessing an actor's name from the description given by your teammate, etc...

title: Le Tour du Lys
description:
Trivia game from the same people who brought us the famous and much loved Le Docte Rat. This time, they chose the Qubec province (Canada) tourist attractions as a theme.

The object of the game is to be the first to reach Qubec, the province's capital. You move around the lily (tour du lys), the province's emblem, trying to reach each of the four predetermined mandatory regions. Once you do, you try to answer correctly one question. After you successfully answered one question for each of these four regions, you have the right to begin your trip towards Qubec which is ruled by a different mechanic.

title: Hoop Hysteria
description:
This is Sportsfan's Hoop Hysteria - The College Basketball Trivia game.

This is an interesting sports trivia game for fans of college basketball.   Each round one player is the offensive team (home team starts) and rolls d6 that has four results (1/6) Turnover - lose possession. (4/6) Shot - Offense selects whether they are attempting 2pt or 3pt shot.   Defense reads the question and if the offense gets it right (separate questions for 2 and 3pt shots) they get the points.   Regardless of whether they answer correctly, play goes to the defense.  (1/6) Shot/Foul - Offense selects 2 or 3pt shot, but if they get it right, they get a shot at the 1pt bonus question too.

From the back of the box :

Over 2,000 questions on NCAA Division I men's basketball trivia.  Contains questions on every major college basketball program.   Includes a scoreboard, a 60-second time, and a custom die.   Scores like a real game.

title: Pop-Up Store Game
description:
From the rules:

This wonderful Toy and Candy Store game with its Pop-Up counters is made especially for children to play going shopping. They have fun as they go from counter to counter, buying articles on their shopping list with play money, and stopping to eat at the soda fountain - just as in a real store.

The object of the game is to complete your shopping list, have the packages wrapped paid for, and be the first to leave the store.

Not much of a game here, but an incredibly cool pop-up board. Allegedly from the 1950s

title: Cup Final
description:
This game is very similar to the Palitoy Striker soccer game, but without the build quality or fun factor.

The pitch is made of a peculiar green material with a strange foam backing that sticks to the carpet; the goals are identical to the one in Striker, but with plastic netting. The game comes supplied with two teams - red and blue, but instead of 5 players per team of Striker, Cup Final only has 3 players on each side.

The two outfield players are plastic with a metal kicking leg, with one player having a bent leg, and one a straight leg. The straight legged player had a scooped foot for lobbing the ball, but this mechanism doesn't work very well. The kicking action is controlled by a button on the back of the base as opposed to the bash 'em on the head mechanism used in Striker. Additionally, the figures are very badly designed, and the slightest movement causes them to fall over (are they Christian Ronaldo in disguise?).

The goalkeepers are identical in design to the original Striker goalkeepers, as they swivel at the waist and have a crooked arm for throwing the ball out.
